G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction lies in this Court under G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the cause of action arose in Somerville, which lies within this county.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of or remedy hazards of which it knew or should have known.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolishes the traditional common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposes on occupiers a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful entrants, rather than specifically recognizing a special “business invitee” duty. The quoted passage is a concurrence criticizing residual reliance on trespasser status; it does not articulate or preserve a distinct invitee standard as stated in the proposition. Thus, the case does not support the proposition that defendant owed plaintiff, as a business invitee, a special invitee-based duty of care.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant, by failing to clean up the spill or post a warning sign despite actual knowledge of the hazardous condition, breached that duty of reasonable care.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The case discusses a business owner's duty to use due care to keep premises reasonably safe or to warn of dangers, and notes that negligence may be shown if the defendant had actual knowledge of a foreign substance. However, in Oliveri there was no evidence that the defendant actually knew of the hazardous condition; the entire analysis concerns whether constructive notice (time on the stair) could be inferred, and the court ultimately holds the evidence insufficient and orders judgment for the defendant. Thus, the opinion does not support a proposition about breach based on actual knowledge and failure to clean or warn; it instead rejects liability on the facts presented.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: "Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance... In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present... for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it."

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant, by failing to clean up the spill or post a warning sign despite actual knowledge of the hazardous condition, breached that duty of reasonable care.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The case abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation rule and holds that property owners owe lawful visitors a general duty of reasonable care with respect to snow and ice, just like other hazards. It does not, however, deal with or articulate a rule about a defendant’s actual knowledge of a spill or hazardous condition indoors, nor does it specifically address breach by "failing to clean up the spill or post a warning sign" despite such knowledge. The cited opinion therefore provides general premises-liability principles but does not establish the specific proposition about actual knowledge and failure to warn or clean up a spill.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

DePonte v. Devon Shores Condo. Trust, 48.raw_text: DePonte v. Devon Shores Condo. Trust, 483 Mass. 174 (2019)
DePonte v. Devon Shores Condo. Trust, 48.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner is liable for injuries to lawful visitors resulting from conditions that the owner knew or reasonably should have known posed an unreasonable risk.

Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.raw_text: Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837 (1987)
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner is liable for injuries to lawful visitors resulting from conditions that the owner knew or reasonably should have known posed an unreasonable risk.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co. does not articulate a general rule that owners are liable for conditions they knew or should have known posed an unreasonable risk. Instead, the concurrence emphasizes that the risk of injury from negligent operation of vehicles at a self-service station was inherent and obvious and expressly concludes there was no duty to warn. That reasoning limits, rather than supports, the claimed proposition of owner liability for such conditions.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger."

Gallant v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.raw_text: Gallant v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co., 343 Mass. 88 (1961)
Gallant v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.proposition: The employee’s admission that he was aware of the spill constitutes actual notice to Defendant.
Gallant v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.support_reasoning: The opinion is an insurance coverage and equity case about which insurer must satisfy a judgment and how dealer’s registration/garage operations affect coverage. It does not address premises liability, spills, store employees, or the concept of an employee’s knowledge constituting actual notice to a defendant. Therefore it cannot be authority for the proposition that an employee’s admission of awareness of a spill constitutes actual notice to the defendant.
Gallant v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.relevant_excerpt: American contends that the car driven by Cosman was not insured by it against liability under coverage A, the clause of its policy which provides for compulsory insurance. It concedes that its policy covers liability arising from the garage company’s operation of its sales agency, but maintains that the coverage does not extend to liability arising from that part of its business concerned with storage.

Foley v. Matulewicz, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 1.raw_text: Foley v. Matulewicz, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 1004 (1984)
Foley v. Matulewicz, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act within a reasonable period after notice of the spill constitutes actionable negligence.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s breach of its duty of care was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses duty, breach, damages, and causation as the elements of negligence but decides only the existence of a duty of care and reverses summary judgment on that basis. The court explicitly leaves to the jury the questions of whether Kask breached her duty and whether any breach was causally related to Officer Jupin’s injuries. Thus, the case does not hold that defendant’s breach was the direct and proximate cause of plaintiff’s injuries; it only allows that issue to proceed to trial.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions … to be the special province of the jury. … We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.proposition: As a direct and foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered bodily injury, pain, suffering, medical expenses, and lost wages.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.support_reasoning: The case is about whether Massachusetts recognizes certain causes of action for emotional distress and prenatal injury in the DES context, not about a specific plaintiff’s proof of bodily injury, pain and suffering, medical expenses, and lost wages resulting from negligence. The opinion explicitly states that negligence and causation are assumed only for purposes of answering certified questions and does not make any holding that, as a direct and foreseeable result of defendant’s negligence, a plaintiff actually suffered those specific categories of damages. Thus it does not provide authority for the proposition as phrased.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.relevant_excerpt: "We note initially that neither the issue of negligence nor that of causation is before us. The certified question assumes both that the defendants were negligent, and that their negligence caused the plaintiffs' emotional distress."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages were not caused in any part by her own comparative fault, but if comparative negligence is alleged, any such percentage should be modest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care recognized under Massachusetts tort law and constitutes negligence entitling Plaintiff to judicial relief.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The case does not hold that the defendant’s conduct fell below the Massachusetts standard of care or that the plaintiffs are entitled to relief. Instead, the SJC affirms summary judgment for the defendant, emphasizing that the plaintiffs failed to prove causation and that there was no evidence linking any alleged breach (including failure to obtain a permit or warn) to the scaffolding collapse. Thus, the opinion is authority against negligence liability on these facts, not in favor of it.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The record reflects that the plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them… No rational jury could find in the plaintiffs’ favor on that issue based on the proffered evidence.”

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care recognized under Massachusetts tort law and constitutes negligence entitling Plaintiff to judicial relief.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.support_reasoning: The case holds that the defendant social host did not owe a common-law duty under Massachusetts tort law because he neither served nor provided alcohol to the intoxicated guest and thus could not be liable in negligence to the injured plaintiff. The Supreme Judicial Court affirms summary judgment for the defendant and explicitly rejects the plaintiff’s theories of negligence and statutory-based liability. Therefore, this opinion stands for the absence of negligence liability in these circumstances, not that the defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care entitling the plaintiff to relief.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.relevant_excerpt: “We think the factor of control should continue to be the dominant consideration in a case of this type.… In the absence of such control in this case, we are not prepared to say that the common law should provide a remedy on the negligent encouragement theory advanced by the plaintiff.… Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort. Judgment affirmed.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award pre-judgment and post-judgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
